repnme.cdata!:
Attracting private capital to help meet
            Vietnam's energy needs

abstracts.cdata!:
With demand for electricity in Vietnam
            growing at an annual average of 13-15 percent over the
            period of 1995-2000, the country needed to increase its
            electricity supplies to sustain its economic growth. In
            2002, half of Vietnam's electric capacity was coming
            from hydropower plants, which is unreliable during times of
            drought. The government decided to promote private sector
            participation as part of its strategy to address the need
            for increased power generation capacity. The Phu My complex
            consists of five gas-fired electricity generation plants,
            70km southeast of Ho Chi Minh City which in time will
            produce up to 4,700 gigawatt hours of power per year.
            Following extensive efforts on energy reform in Vietnam
            through numerous projects aimed at delivering affordable
            energy to rural areas, as well as upgrading existing
            capacity to meet the growing demands of urban areas, IDA
            helped finance the first phase of the Phu My 2 (PM2) power
            project. Another part of the World Bank Group, the
            Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) provided
            risk guarantees to Singaporean and French investors. As one
            of the country's first power Build-Operate-Transfer
            project, PM3 is creating a roadmap for others on the
            responsibilities and sequencing of plant transfer to locals.
            The project is also a good model for public-private partnership.

24040119.trustfund:
TF023485-USDOE-ALTERNATIVE ENERGY ACTIVITIES,TF033465-VIETNAM - POWER, GAS,TF033688-VIETNAM - POWER DEVELOPMENT,TF033826-VIETNAM - POWER,TF033827-VIETNAM - POWER,TF034042-VIETNAM - POWER,TF034534-VIETNAM - ENERGY SECTOR
            INVESTMENT AND POLICY REVIEW UPDATE

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory, and
            sustainability is highly likely. The performance of the Bank
            was highly satisfactory, stemming from a project design that
            fitted with the prevailing sectoral objectives,
            straightforward procurement arrangements, and project
            supervision that worked closely with the borrower, namely
            the presence of an energy team in the field office. The
            performance of the Borrower was satisfactory, with
            appropriate entities involved in assisting the Bank in the
            overall design, and providing relevant technical, and
            financial inputs. Regardless of success, some key lessons
            may be drawn from the project, mainly that the need for
            coordination with the International Finance Corporation
            (IFC), in the preparation of a fast track project, involving
            the private sector within time, and budget constraints,
            would ensure smooth project preparation. For although the
            Government decided that it was not prepared to risk delays
            with the IFC's proposal, nor was it ready to establish
            a separate entity with majority private ownership, the issue
            was resolved by agreeing to the Bank's condition
            (build, operate, transfer approach), which ensured private
            sector participation. The protracted process of government
            approvals, such as long-term gas contract, and tariff
            adjustment, were risks much higher than envisioned, but
            flexibility, and the above-average staff skills demonstrated
            through all project stages, proved successful.

18153203.trustfund:
TF033827-VIETNAM - POWER,TF033688-VIETNAM - POWER DEVELOPMENT,TF033826-VIETNAM - POWER,TF034534-VIETNAM - ENERGY SECTOR
            INVESTMENT AND POLICY REVIEW UPDATE,TF023485-USDOE-ALTERNATIVE ENERGY ACTIVITIES,TF033465-VIETNAM - POWER, GAS
18153203.majtheme: Rural development,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Power
            Development Project are to: 1) help meet the rapid growth in
            electricity demand in the South of Viet Nam through the
            addition of new gas-fired generating capacity; 2) strengthen
            the high voltage (HV) transformation capacity in Viet Nam;
            3) assist the government in the introduction of private
            power in the country; 4) strengthen the institutional
            capacity of Electricity of Viet Nam (EVN) through technical
            assistance and training; and 5) assist in the formulation of
            a national strategy and master plan for rural
            electrification. The project will finance the following
            components: 1) installation of 2x150 megawatt (MW) gas
            turbines for the first 450 MW Combined Cycle (CC) power
            block of the Phu My power station; 2) addition of about 900
            megavolt-amperes (MVA) of such capacity in other parts of
            the country; 3) resettlement and compensation of persons
            affected by the Phu My plant; and 4) consulting services
            for: (a) project design and supervision for Phu My; (b)
            development of a Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) type of
            arrangement for the second CC power block of Phu My on the
            basis of competitive bidding; (c) technical assistance and
            training for EVN managerial staff; (d) master plan for rural
            electrification; and (e) technical studies for the Dai Ninh
            hydropower project.

696789.trustfund:
TF023485-USDOE-ALTERNATIVE ENERGY ACTIVITIES,TF034534-VIETNAM - ENERGY SECTOR
            INVESTMENT AND POLICY REVIEW UPDATE,TF033827-VIETNAM - POWER,TF033826-VIETNAM - POWER,TF033465-VIETNAM - POWER, GAS,TF033688-VIETNAM - POWER DEVELOPMENT,TF034042-VIETNAM - POWER

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Power
            Development Project are to: 1) help meet the rapid growth in
            electricity demand in the South of Viet Nam through the
            addition of new gas-fired generating capacity; 2) strengthen
            the high voltage (HV) transformation capacity in Viet Nam;
            3) assist the government in the introduction of private
            power in the country; 4) strengthen the institutional
            capacity of Electricity of Viet Nam (EVN) through technical
            assistance and training; and 5) assist in the formulation of
            a national strategy and master plan for rural
            electrification. The project will finance the following
            components: 1) installation of 2x150 megawatt (MW) gas
            turbines for the first 450 MW Combined Cycle (CC) power
            block of the Phu My power station; 2) addition of about 900
            megavolt-amperes (MVA) of such capacity in other parts of
            the country; 3) resettlement and compensation of persons
            affected by the Phu My plant; and 4) consulting services
            for: (a) project design and supervision for Phu My; (b)
            development of a Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) type of
            arrangement for the second CC power block of Phu My on the
            basis of competitive bidding; (c) technical assistance and
            training for EVN managerial staff; (d) master plan for rural
            electrification; and (e) technical studies for the Dai Ninh
            hydropower project.
